header.title: National Living Wage to be raised to £10.50 for everyone over 21
header.postText: Sajid Javid has announced an increase in the National Living Wage to £10.50 by 2024.', 'He also said he would expand the reach of the mandatory minimum wage to cover all workers over the age of 21, down from the present 25.', 'The chancellor made the announcement at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester.', 'He said: ‘Over the next five years, we will make the UK the first major economy in the world to end low pay altogether.’', 'Mr Javid said he was setting a new target for the ‘National Living Wage’, raising it to match two-thirds of median earnings and ‘giving four million people a well-earned pay rise’.', 'The previous National Living Wage was set at £8.21 for those 25 and over and £7.70 for 21 to 24.', 'Currently, for those between the ages of 18 and 20, the rate is set at £6.15.', 'The chancellor also said that ‘deal or no deal’ the country will be prepared to deal with the consequences.', 'Mr Javid said the ‘main concern of businesses was the threat posed to them by the Labour party’.', 'It comes as he also announced a spending blitz worth billions of pounds to bring about an ‘infrastructure revolution’, prioritising roads, buses and broadband.', 'Mr Javid also announced plans for further devolution to cities across the country.', 'The chancellor also pledged £25bn towards road projects, £220m for bus improvements and £5bn for digital infrastructure in his speech, along with extra funding for youth services.', 'The Labour party meanwhile said it would get to £10 for all, including under 18s by next year.', 'Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. For more stories like this, check our news page.

commentThread.commentText: Can't see the majority of employers complying with this - my son worked very late hours, physically demanding and unpleasant and only got £8 an hour. If employers have to pay higher hourly rates many will simply demand people work harder, for fewer hours.

replies.commentText: Bill Smith We're sadly a long way away from full employment though. I doubt it will happen again in my lifetime.

Bill Smith What Sandra said, also I don't think you understand how low paid, low status employment works: zero hour contracts, exploitation of young people and others who lack the options for anything better.My sons' workplace closed, he has applied for others, not even heard back because so many people go for these jobs. Turnover is extremely high, it is 'chew them up spit them out' in low paid, low status work.

commentThread.commentText: The price of everything served by people on NMW will go up. It also undermines jobs that pay out between the current and proposed wage so expect an increase to the cost of those services too.The interesting part is whether the income tax threshold will increase or whether the lowest earners will suddenly find they're being taxed where they previously weren't due to being under the minimum amount.Those people will then find the cost of living has increased due to the cost of lowered paid services and round it goes...

replies.commentText: Michael Welburn "All these poor nmw earners should be grateful?"I didn't use those words at all or even that sentiment.
so they remain poorly paid so you can get to buy more..got it it's all about you. ...
Alison Webster ????What????Who has said that?

A calculator and a few minutes resolves your "really interesting part":Now = £7.70 x 37.5 x 52 = £15,015- £12,500 = £2,515 * 0.2 = £503Income = £15,015 - £503 = £14,512Then = £10.50 x 37.5 x 52 = £20,475- £12,500 = £7,975 * 0.2 = £1,595Income = £20,475 - £1,595 = £18,880So even without an increase in threshold, they're still better off £4,368. Not a small amount for small employers to find - a large knock-on effect for all salaries - but little thought given to that evil lot, all flash cars, no money worries or constant worry of sick notes arriving for "anxiety" and related health issues!

Go the extra mile, prove you're worth more than X and employer will pay it. If you've a problem with the wage, don't apply in the first place and let someone else have a crack of the whip.

commentThread.commentText: I find it amazing how many ppl can justify low wages by saying silly things like companies will go out of business and cost of living will rise etc. Hate to point something out, dear neighbours in the UK, your cost of living has risen dramatically in the last 10 yrs and yet the minimum wage hasn't...
Then everything else shoots up in price and we're back exactly where we were in the beginning.
That's a big cut in Mp's wages then!!!

I think this is a very sly tactic from the government. They increase the minimum wage every year but the threshold for benefit entitlement will stay the same. "Oh your £6.23 over the threshold for your benefits?" Blam!! Were taking all your monthly benefits off you, you make enough money now,deal with it. Like that the government wins and we always lose. Inflation means the price of everyday items will be more expensive anyways so won't make any difference,it'd make a difference now not then. Theres a big difference between National Minimum Wage & National Living Wage, ones mandatory the other isn't....guess which one isn't?
It'll be £2.50 for a loaf of breed by then anyways so won't make a shred of difference 😂😂😂
